entry.et: Middle English crouden, from Old English crūdan; akin to Middle High German kroten to crowd, Old English crod multitude, Middle Irish gruth curds

def.dt: :to press close the players crowded around the coach
:to fill by pressing or thronging together a room crowded with children
:to press, force, or thrust into a small space
:push force often used with off or out crowd a person off the sidewalk
:to put on (sail) in excess of the usual for greater speed
:to put pressure on don't crowd me, I'll pay
:to press or stand close to the batter was crowding the plate
:a large number of persons especially when collected together :throng
:most of one's peers follow the crowd
:a large number of things close together I saw a crowd…of golden daffodils William Wordsworth
:a group of people having something (as a habit, interest, or occupation) in common in with the wrong crowd the Hollywood crowd

entry.pt: crowd throng horde crush mob mean an assembled multitude. crowd implies a close gathering and pressing together a crowd gathered. throng and horde suggest movement and pushing a throng of reporters a horde of shoppers. crush emphasizes the compactness of the group, the difficulty of individual movement, and the attendant discomfort a crush of fans. mob implies a disorderly crowd with the potential for violence an angry mob.

entry.et: Middle English crowde, from Middle Welsh crwth

def.dt: :an ancient Celtic stringed instrument that is plucked or bowed called also crwth
:one (as a performer or product) that is notably or reliably popular or appealing a flamboyant crowd–pleaser given to mad feats of daring Tony Hendra
